Background and Analysis:
	 
Presented to the Board for ratification is the list of contracts and agreements signed by the Vice Chancellor, Business Services. It is in the intention of Business Services to present such a list each month.
	 
This procedure is in response to a review of Education Code requirements and board policy section 3000.

Kevin McElroy, ext. 6201
Additional contact names:

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In November 2012, we were informed by the Santa Clara County Office of Education that in the Fall of 2012 CalSTRS will evaluate employers, including fiscally accountable school district entities, to determine if they are eligible to report directly to CalSTRS starting fiscal year 2013/2014.  On April 12, 2013, CalSTRS notified the district that we passed the CalSTRS evaluation and our district is approved to become a direct reporter effective in fiscal year 2013/14. We met the CalSTRS direct reporting requirements and the direct reporting will take effect upon CalSTRS’ receipt of the attached approved District Board resolution.
	 
CalSTRS direct reporting requirements:
·      History of accurate and timely reporting habits 
·      District must have their own payroll system 
·      Complete control over district funds 
·      Full compliance with the F496 File Specifications
·      Affirms that district will be responsible for submitting contribution data/remittances including any/all previous adjustments and new reporting from the time prior to the effective date of direct reporting. 
·      Affirms that the District is responsible for any penalty assessments for data reported as a direct reporter subsequent to the effective date of direct reporting. 
	 
Submitted by:
Kevin McElroy
Additional contact names:
Hector Quinonez, Nancy Chao
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Staff recommend that the Board approve the attached Board Resolution.
items.item_text: Establish the District as a Direct Report Source that Reports Defined Benefit Contributions Directly to CalSTRS
items.item_text_raw: 2. Establish the District as a Direct Report Source that Reports Defined Benefit Contributions Directly to CalSTRS

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District has contracted for the management of Flint Center events for many years.  Domus Aurea, Inc. has been the authorized contractor for the past 15 years.
	 
The District has continued to partner with Domus Aurea to manage the Flint Center operations because; 1) knowledge of the local entertainment market; 2) past successful experience in similar markets; 3) managerial strength; and 4) financial stability. Domus Aurea, Inc. has a 15-year history with the District and has performed well in a competitive entertainment market despite the unique challenges of operating a 2300-seat venue on a college campus and the past several years of economic downturn.  Based upon its evaluation, staff recommends that the Board approve a new three-year agreement with Domus Aurea, Inc. The scope of this contract continues our current long standing relationship and includes the following;
	 
Duties of Operator:
Programming a broad range of events consistent with the District’s objectives including a commitment to community based performing arts groups
		 
Contracting with vendors, promoters and/or agents in addition to employing personnel and contractors to operate all aspects of the facility
		 
Managing fiscal activities, compliance issues and day to day operations, which include:
âMaintenance and site improvement
Marketing strategies to enhance Flint Center operations
First rate concessions and other merchandising aspects
Other business operating strategies to optimize return on its ventures
The terms of the new contract closely parallel the terms of the existing contract. Contract details have been updated as appropriate through legal review by district counsel and negotiated between the Vice Chancellor of Business Services and Domus Aurea, Inc.
	 
Submitted by:
Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor Business Services
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Vice Chancellor of Business Services Kevin McElroy recommends that the Board approve the new contract with Domus Aurea, Inc. for Flint Center facilities management and entertainment programming services for the period July 1, 2013, through June 30, 2017.
items.item_text: Contract for Flint Center Facilities Management and Entertainment Programming Services
items.item_text_raw: 3. Contract for Flint Center Facilities Management and Entertainment Programming Services

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
This year is the final year of a three-year study undertaken to conduct qualitative and quantitative research regarding essential practices in serving student veterans with and student veterans without disabilities in the California Community College System. The project is at the behest of the CCC Chancellor’s Office and is being overseen by the Chancellor’s  Office and the  High Tech Center Training Unit. The primary researcher is Wayne K. Miller II, PhD.
	 
The project originally began in 2011. The third and final phase will be completed no later than June 30, 2014.
	 
The cost for this phase of the research, payable to the primary researcher Wayne K. Miller II, PhD is $130,000 in eight equal monthly installments of $16,250 beginning August 1, 2013. Additionally, there may be as many as five trips required to fulfill the data objectives of the research. Each trip will be 100% reimbursed excluding any out-of-pocket expenses of researcher at CCCS approved travel rates up to an amount of $10,000. The total cost of this contract is $140,000.
	 
A final report covering the scope of the three-year project and the conclusions derived from the data will be delivered electronically no later than June 30, 2014.
	 
Submitted by:
Brian Murphy, President, ext. 8936
Additional contact names:
Stacey Cook, Vice President Student Services, ext. 8330
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: De Anza College President, Brian Murphy recommends approval of the Independent Contractor Agreement for Wayne K Miller in the amount of $140,000.
items.item_text: Independent Contractor Agreement for Wayne K. Miller - VRC Survey Phase Three
items.item_text_raw: 13. Independent Contractor Agreement for Wayne K. Miller - VRC Survey Phase Three

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Under Pension Reform, new regulations require that all retirees must serve a 180-day wait period following retirement prior to being reemployed in a STRS/PERS eligible position. Failure to do so places the retiree’s pension earnings at risk whereby any compensation earned during the first 180 days will reduce pension earnings and/or require reinstatement from retirement. The regulations also provide however that an exception may be granted under the condition that the Governing Board approves such resolution in an Open Meeting as a separate item not on a consent agenda, that certifies the nature of the employment and that the appointment is necessary to fill a critically needed position before 180 days have passed.
	 
Request for Exception:
De Anza College is requesting exception to the 180-day wait period for Susan Bloom, Financial Aid Coordinator, to work as a temporary employee starting 7/2/13 immediately following her retirement on June 30, 2013, due to the need to fill this critical position prior to the expiration of the 180-day waiting period. Expected duration of the appointment is July 2, 2013 through September 30, 2013.
	 
Background Regarding This Unfilled Position:
The college completed and submitted the position documentation and recruitment requisition shortly after Ms. Bloom’s February letter of retirement was submitted. They began recruiting for the coordinator position in March, following Board approval of Ms. Bloom’s retirement. The search process began in March, including forming the committee, posting the position, and proceeding with collection and review of applications and interview of selected applicants. However, based on an assessment and determination (June 10) of candidates, no one was selected to fill the Financial Aid Coordinator position. 
	 
Justification:
The College was unable to fill her position before her retirement at the end of this month, but her work in disbursing student financial aid and handling related key functions (see attached) have to be performed without interruption. This position cannot be performed by other existing staff in the office or another temporary employee due to the highly technical and specialized nature of most of the responsibilities assigned this position, which also requires authorization and access to various Department of Education sites and systems. Considering the new Director of Financial Aid will not begin working until after July 1, the College needs a Financial Aid Coordinator now with the experience, access and authorization to do the work and to provide critical transition for the new Director of Financial Aid. 
	 
This position is critical to maintain compliance with federal rules and regulations. The College must avoid another federal audit finding with the Return to Title IV aid. The District could receive a financial penalty if found to be out of compliance again.
	 
Submitted by:
Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources & Equal Opportunity 
Additional contact names:
Suzanne Pfeiffer, Director of Human Resources x6109
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources and Equal Opportunity recommends approval of the attached Resolution authorizing exception for hiring under the 180-day wait period for PERS/STRS post-retirement reemployment for Susan Bloom.
items.item_text: Resolution Authorizing Exception to the 180-day Wait Period for PERS/STRS Post-Retirement Reemployment: Susan Bloom, Financial Aid Coordinator (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 20. Resolution Authorizing Exception to the 180-day Wait Period for PERS/STRS Post-Retirement Reemployment: Susan Bloom, Financial Aid Coordinator (ACTION)

Project Name:  Modernization of Learning Support Center, Biology, and General Classrooms
Amount:  $5,738
For:
	 
Addition of a classroom sign, as requested by the College; addition of a raised curb for disabled pathway definition for added safety; and revision of fire alarm cable routing due to site conditions.  A 14-day no cost time extension for an interim milestone is granted to the Contractor due to the site condition delays. The final completion date of the overall project is not affected.
	 
This change plus all previously approved change orders equal to 2.3% of the base contract value. 
	 
Because this project is being built under two DSA permit numbers, each portion of the project must be tracked separately for DSA.  As a result there are currently two Change Order #1 documents; this portion of the project has been designated 105A to differentiate it from the second portion.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The ETS Department refreshes and replaces computer equipment on a five-year cycle for student classroom labs as well as for faculty and staff.  ETS projects that between 1500 and 1600 desktops and laptops will be up for refresh in fiscal year 2013-2014.  Therefore, Purchasing Services expects to issue several large quantity purchase orders for Dell and Apple computer equipment between now and June 30, 2014, some that will exceed the current statutory bid threshold of $83,400 per purchase order. In accordance with the California Public Contract Code (PCC) Section 20651(a) through (d), only the governing board may authorize award of such purchase orders, and the board must award the orders to the lowest responsible bidder or reject all bids. However, in lieu of conducting a bid process, Public Contract Code (PCC) section 20652 provides that community college districts may utilize contracts that have been awarded by other public entities. 
	 
The required Apple and Dell products are available to the District on two Western States Contracting Alliance (WSCA) contracts.  WSCA is a contracting consortium for state government departments, institutions, agencies and political subdivisions in the states of Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, Minnesota, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, South Dakota, Utah, Washington and Wyoming.  The WSCA Master Price Agreement B27158 with Apple is currently valid through August 31, 2014. The WSCA Master Price Agreement B27160 with Dell is also currently valid through August 31, 2014.  Contracts and links to vendor pricing are posted at: http://www.mmd.admin.state.mn.us/wsca/2009-2014_contracts.asp.
	 
WSCA contract pricing is based upon the combined volume of several states and their political subdivisions. Each WSCA contract’s “Products and Services Schedule” (PSS) shows the maximum price offered to participating entities and provides that each entity may negotiate large order discounts. Additionally, the District is entitled to each vendor’s education discounts and may also benefit whenever the vendors announce promotional prices and/or general price reductions.  Given that the District is standardized on Apple and Dell equipment and product lines, if it were to conduct a separate bid rather than using the WSCA contracts, the sole qualified bidders would be Apple and Dell. A bid based only upon the District’s anticipated purchases would be unlikely to result in lower prices than those available through the WSCA contract. Prior to issuing each purchase order, District staff will contact the vendor to obtain a price quotation. The price quoted will be the lowest available to the District on that date for the specified products and quantities.
	 
ETS estimates that some of the purchase order quantities for student classroom labs could exceed the current statutory bid threshold of $83,400. They are:
	 
Foothill Campus Labs:  Biology Department – 102 District standard Dell and Apple Desktops, and several other labs and departments – 124 District standard Apple Desktops, 43 District standard Apple Laptops, 156 District standard Dell Desktops and 8 District standard Dell Laptops. 
De Anza Campus Labs: Advance Technology Center (ATC) – 169 District standard Apple Desktops and 361 District standard Dell Desktops, and several other labs – 104 District standard Apple Desktops, 89 District standard Dell Desktops, and 44 District standard Dell Laptops. 
	 
The computers will be paid for from Measure C funding for the refresh of technology equipment. The aggregate estimated cost for the student classroom labs in FY 13-14 is $1,328,000 plus applicable sales tax.  The classroom lab equipment may be replaced in kind, or it may be replaced with new or different, less expensive Apple and Dell technologies to meet each program need. 
	 
Submitted by:
  Gina Bailey, Int. Director, Purchasing Services and Material Services
Additional contact names:
  Joe Moreau, Sharon Luciw, Jose Rueda
Is backup provided?
  No
items.item_recommendation: To take advantage of the volume price discounts of WSCA Master Agreement B27158 for Apple and B27160 for Dell, authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services to issue purchase orders for Apple and Dell products in excess of the legally mandated bid threshold through June 30, 2014 pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652.
items.item_text: Authorization to purchase Apple and Dell Computers in excess of the bid threshold (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 26. Authorization to purchase Apple and Dell Computers in excess of the bid threshold (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District Purchasing Services Department prepared bid documents and incorporated technical specifications jointly written with ETS staff in order to invite bids for a three-year contract (renewable for up to two additional one-year periods) to purchase multimedia equipment, programming, engineering services, and installation labor as required using Measure C funds.  The bid document required bidders and their listed subcontractors to enter into the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Program Agreement (PSA) between the District and the Santa Clara and San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council.
 
The bid was advertised on May 3, 2013 and May 10, 2013.  The “Invitation to Bid” was sent to four (4) vendors, as well as, posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  On May 17, 2013, Purchasing Services and ETS conducted a non-mandatory pre-bid conference and made site visits with attendees to typical multimedia classrooms.   Representatives from two vendors attended the pre-bid conference and vendors were required to submit bids for equipment and labor based upon estimated quantities and typical room configurations.  On June 7, 2013, Purchasing Services staff publicly opened and read bids.  Both vendors that attended the pre-bid conference submitted bids.  The bid results are shown below:
 
 
Signal Perfection Limited
Spinitar
Programming, Engineering Services, and Installation Labor 
$813,113.00
$770,973.50
Equipment (including tax)
$3,770,726.02
$3,963,559.62
Grand Total for Equipment and Labor
$4,583,839.02
$4,820,989.36
 
Purchases of multimedia equipment and installation will be made based upon the availability of funds in Measure C accounts.  The total expenditures over the next three years may be more or less than $4,583,839.02, depending on actual room requirements.
 
The Board of Trustees previously awarded Bid 1167 to SPL Integrated Solutions in 2008.  Furthermore, Signal Perfection Limited has signed and submitted the PSA with its bid.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Interim Director of Purchasing Services, ext. 6165
Additional contact names:
Jose Rueda, Bill Matsumoto, Dawn Allshouse
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services, Gina Bailey, to execute an agreement Not To Exceed $4.6 million, in accordance with Bid 1627 contract prices, terms, and conditions for a three-year term with an option to renew provided that funds are available, with the lowest responsible bidder, Signal Perfection Limited.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The project will replace and repair the concrete roof/walkway and guardrail above the pool supply storage rooms.  The scope of work includes waterproofing, replacement of storm drain system, and a new sanitary drain system along Building 2700 and the pool supply storage rooms. The scope of work also includes sandblasting of lead paint, patching of wall spalling, paint, and replacement of wall & ceiling-mounted electrical in the storage rooms. 
	 
Allana, Buick & Bers, Inc. prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department. 
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on May 8, 2013, and May 15, 2013.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  A mandatory bid walk was held on May 21, 2013, and a total of seven (7) contractors attended the walk.  Bids were publicly opened and read on June 6, 2013 in the Purchasing Services office.  One contractor submitted a bid and the bid result is summarized below:
	 
BID RESULTS
	 
Contractor
Base Bid Proposal Amount:
Rodan Builders, Inc.
$459,000
	 
According to Public Contract Code (PCC), Section 20651(b): “The governing board shall let any contract for a public project, as defined in subdivision (c) of Section 22002, involving an expenditure of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000) or more to the lowest responsible bidder who shall give security as the board requires, or else reject all bids.” 
	 
The bid submitted by Rodan Builders, Inc. the bid price exceeds the architect’s estimate of $350,000 and would cause the overall project budget of $472,443 to be exceeded as well.  Therefore, the District recommends that the Board reject the bid received for Bid #1590-118, Pool Storage Rooms Repairs.   The District’s Program Manager along with Gilbane/MAAS will work together to determine the next steps for a possible future re-bid of this project.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Interim Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, Art Heinrich, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: In accordance with PCC 20651(b), reject the bid received for Bid #1590-118, Pool Storage Rooms Repairs at Foothill College.
items.item_text: Reject all bids received for Pool Storage Rooms Repairs at Foothill College, Bid #1590-118 (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 28. Reject all bids received for Pool Storage Rooms Repairs at Foothill College, Bid #1590-118 (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The project includes the renovation and repair of the existing Environmental Studies Area pond including a new clay liner and new root barrier system, mechanical/electrical renovations to support the pond infrastructure, and ADA compliant pathways.
	 
Ecovation Group is the landscape architect for the project, and Keller & Daseking Architects is the DSA architect of record.  A complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department. 
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on April 18, 2013, and April 25, 2013.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  A mandatory bid walk was held on May 2, 2013, and a total of seven (7) general contractors attended the walk.  Bids were publicly opened and read on June 6, 2013 by Purchasing Services.  One contractor submitted a bid and the bid result is summarized below:
	 
BID RESULTS
	 
Contractor
Base Bid Proposal Amount:
Guerra Construction Group
$827,000
	 
According to Public Contract Code, Section (PCC) 20651(b): “The governing board shall let any contract for a public project, as defined in subdivision (c) of Section 22002, involving an expenditure of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000) or more to the lowest responsible bidder who shall give security as the board requires, or else reject all bids.” 
	 
The bid submitted by Guerra Construction Group exceeds the landscape architect’s construction estimate and the construction budget of $400,000.  Therefore, the construction bond management team recommends that the Board reject the bid received for Bid #1646-229R, Environmental Studies Area.  De Anza College District’s Program Manager and Gilbane/MAAS will work together to determine the next steps for a possible future re-bid of this project.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Interim Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, Tom Armstrong, Donna Jones-Dulin, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: In accordance with PCC 20651(b), reject the bid received for Bid #1646-229R, Environmental Studies Area at De Anza College.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On September 10, 2012, the Board of Trustees authorized award of a Preconstruction Services Agreement to C. W. Driver (CWD) as the Lease-Leaseback contractor for the Educational Center (Project). The Board also approved the Site Lease, Facilities Lease and Construction Provisions as to form and content.  The Preconstruction Services Agreement requires CWD to develop a Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) for site demolition and for following Project construction phases.
	 
Under the Site Lease and the Facilities Lease, the District will lease District-owned land to CWD, and CWD will agree to prepare the Project site and to construct the Project pursuant to the GMP, the District’s Construction Provisions, and CWD’s responses to RFQ/RFP 1469-801.  The District will receive incremental title to the constructed property in accordance with payments made.  The District will pay for and take title to all improvements no later than completion of construction of the Project, at which time the leases will be terminated.
	 
Because it is advantageous to remove existing buildings as soon as possible, CWD solicited competitive bids to develop a $3,744,150 GMP for the Demolition Phase only. The Demolition Phase GMP is subject to adjustments for extra work and changes as directed and agreed to by the District. The GMP includes demolition of some buildings and improvements located on adjacent parcels owned by the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) and the City of Sunnyvale (City).  The District will be reimbursed for the costs of that work under a Memorandum of Agreement between the District and the City and a similar Memorandum of Agreement between the District and VA.  The Board of Trustees previously approved both Memoranda.
	 
Two following phases of work to complete the project are planned: an Early Site Work Phase and a Building and Site Construction Phase.  Amendments to the Facilities Lease will be made to address the GMP for those phases. The construction budget for all project phases is $25,000,000. Upon execution of the Site Lease and the Facilities Lease, CWD will be given control of the site to commence work. Demolition is expected to be complete by March 2014.  Project occupancy is scheduled for January 2016.
	 
This action item is to award the Site Lease and Facilities Lease agreements to CWD and to authorize CWD to proceed with demolition activities to construct the project (the Demolition Phase). District staff will later seek approval of modifications to the Facilities Lease agreement that will authorize an Early Site Work Phase and a Building and Site Construction Phase for construction of the project based upon DSA-approved construction documents for an amount not to exceed the GMP for each phase. Demolition does not require the Division of State Architects (DSA) review.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, x6165
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, x6150; Art Heinrich, x6295
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Authorize Gina Bailey, Interim Director of Purchasing Services, to award the Site Lease and the Facilities Lease to C. W. Driver and accept the GMP in the amount of $3,744,150 for the Demolition Phase of the Project.
items.item_text: Authorize award of a Site Lease and a Facilities Lease to C. W. Driver for the Foothill – De Anza Educational Center in Sunnyvale, California (Measure C Project #801) and accept the GMP in the amount of $3,744,150 for the Demolition Phase of the Project (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 30. Authorize award of a Site Lease and a Facilities Lease to C. W. Driver for the Foothill – De Anza Educational Center in Sunnyvale, California (Measure C Project #801) and accept the GMP in the amount of $3,744,150 for the Demolition Phase of the Project (ACTION)
